name: Bebe Rexha
description:
'''Bleta''' "'''Bebe'''" '''Rexha''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|b|iː|b|i|_|ˈ|r|ɛ|k|s|ə}} {{respell|BEE|bee|_|REK|sə}}, {{IPA|sq|ˈblɛta ˈɾɛdʒa|lang}}; born August 30, 1989) is an American singer and songwriter. She signed with [[Warner Records]] in 2013, and was credited with co-writing releases of other artists—such as [[Eminem]]'s [[Grammy Award]]-winning single "[[The Monster (song)|The Monster]]"—before furthering her career as a recording artist. Her debut [[extended play]] (EP), ''[[I Don't Wanna Grow Up]]'' (2015), did not chart domestically, although its single "[[I'm Gonna Show You Crazy]]" entered several international charts.

Rexha released two additional EPs in 2017: ''[[All Your Fault: Pt. 1]]'' and ''[[All Your Fault: Pt. 2]]'', both of which spawned the singles "[[I Got You (Bebe Rexha song)|I Got You]]" and "[[The Way I Are (Dance with Somebody)]]" (featuring [[Lil Wayne]]). Rexha saw further success with her collaborations such as "[[Hey Mama (David Guetta song)|Hey Mama]]" (with [[David Guetta]], [[Nicki Minaj]] and [[Afrojack]]), "[[Me, Myself & I (G-Eazy and Bebe Rexha song)|Me, Myself & I]]" (with [[G-Eazy]]), "[[In the Name of Love (Martin Garrix and Bebe Rexha song)|In the Name of Love]]" (with [[Martin Garrix]]), and "[[Meant to Be (Bebe Rexha song)|Meant to Be]]" (featuring [[Florida Georgia Line]]); the latter peaked at number two on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Country Duo/Group Performance|Best Country Duo/Group Performance]] at the [[61st Grammy Awards]]. Rexha's debut studio album, ''[[Expectations (Bebe Rexha album)|Expectations]]'' (2018), peaked at number 13 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] and yielded her a nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best New Artist|Best New Artist]] that same year. Her second and third albums, ''[[Better Mistakes]]'' (2021) and [[Bebe (album)|''Bebe'']] (2023), both lukewarmly entered the ''Billboard'' 200; the latter included the single "[[I'm Good (Blue)]]" (with [[David Guetta]]), which peaked at number four on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 and topped the charts in 22 countries.
